  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14019].

This issue is a follow up on the comment raised at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Remote+API+Specification#comment-168004177.

We're using Confluence as a documentation authoring environment.
As such, we periodically download content from Confluence for translation into various languages. [this content is then passed into a translation management system].

Not all versions of a page are fit to be translated, so we routinely have authors save a version with the comment  "Ready for translation". 
Then, the author might continue to edit the page. 

However, right now, with the remote api, we can neither read version comments, nor download anything other than the current version of the page.

What we need to be able to do through the API is:
1. Loop through all versions a particular page, and find the most recent version that has a particular comment, like, say - "ready for translation".

2. I then want to pull down that version's content.

For it to work, I think I need:

- the 'save comment' to be part of the PageHistorySummary object

Both of these features are available in MediaWiki's API - and that allows for a more dynamic documentation authoring environment.

Appreciate anything you can do on this.
fields.summary: Make a page's various revisions and their associated save-comments readable through the API.

I've created this issue against Confluence, because it's the main application I'm concerned with here, though this is an issue with JIRA as well as your other applications.

We have a Crowd+JIRA+Confluence+Crucible+Fisheye installation. The major thing thats come back every time from feedback has been that there should be a way to navigate quickly between each of the applications.

I've attempted to do this using the Custom HTML feature in Confluence and by editing the templates in JIRA, with some limited success. I've not been able to get the tabs looking the same on both applications because of the limitations of the CSS and HTML that is there. Attached is examples with the current results. HTML + CSS can be supplied.

So here is my suggestion:

Confluence (and all other Atlassian applications) should have a switch that lets you enable a 'Top Navigation Bar' which enables a bar similar to the one I've shown here, that lets you add a customisable list of links. The style should be the same across all applications and behave consistently, with a configurable highlight to show the currently selected application.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13864].
  {panel}

There's a few places where we can indicate read-only transactions to the Spring transaction wrappers. This removes the need for Hibernate to do a dirty check as part of it's "flush-if-necessary" check at the end of the transaction interceptor and improves performance.

Specifically, the following should be read-only:

- DAO transaction interceptor, get* methods
- PermissionManager interceptor, has* methods
- Plugin transaction interceptor, get* methods.

Additionally, get* methods on UserAccessor can be read-only except for ones that access property sets.
fields.summary: Improve performance by configuring read-only transactions on more Spring proxies

1. Develop a monitoring framework within Confluence
a) specify concrete action triggers (by default)
b) allow users to tune these triggers according to their needs
eg. recognise import version of XML and ban it with an error, preventing imports from *not* the same major version to fail
eg. memory trigger - when reaching more than 90% of memory usage for more than 20 sec (as one would expect sudden spikes in memory usage, yet not necessary long lasting ones)
eg. usage patterns
eg. broken/outdated macros
eg. cache is not tunes

2. Specify Admin group to be notified on events
Upon any of the above triggers, confluence will send a blog to the pre-defined group of people and also can produce a report in an Admin > Reports section

3. Option to integrate with internal 'Log Analysis' tool
Fetch new error file description from ATL server and run analysis tool to provide report when pre-configured trigger occurs.

4. Hooking up into 'Create Support Request' feature

There is a plethora of events which the application can be _made_ to monitor. I'd suggest to first create the reporting framework (as the blogging framework already exists) and implement one or two items from the list. We can keep adding to it in the future.
fields.summary: Confluence blogging when problem is to occur

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13798].
  {panel}

Currently the upgrade process checks the build ID against confluence.cfg.xml to see whether the user is trying to upgrade. In addition, the build number stored in the database should be checked to prevent problematic upgrades.

Customers might inadvertently do the following while trying to upgrade Confluence:

# Install latest version distribution
# Create new database
# Run through setup wizard
# Restore sql dump from old version

The procedure is completely broken because it loses all information stored in the home directory (such as attachments), but Confluence doesn't currently do anything to prevent it.

At the moment, the upgrade process does not start because the home directory version number (in confluence.cfg.xml) matches the build number stored in the application itself. The application starts up with the old data, and with a reindex it can look as if Confluence is mostly working. Only much later can the failure of some operation with the home directory data expose the upgrade as a complete disaster.

If the upgrade process also checked the version number stored in the database and stopped Confluence starting if the home directory and database didn't match, it would make this situation easier to diagnose and prevent customers using Confluence after such a failed upgrade.
fields.summary: Prevent Confluence startup if version of home directory and database do not match (to stop inadvertent attempt to upgrade via database backup)

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-13637].
  {panel}

The encoding test page (http://localhost:8080/admin/encodingtestrun.action) doesn't provide instructions to test for Asian languages such as Japanese, Chinese.  If they followed the provided instructions, they may assume their database supports Internationalization because the sample text we instruct users to paste will appear correct, but Japanese will not.

For example, if they paste Japanese into the box instead, it will fail with upside-down question marks.  This was produced under these conditions:
* Confluence 2.9.2
* Oracle Express Edition 10g (Western European) with encoding WE8MSWIN1252.
fields.summary: Encoding Test should cover more languages
